Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Productivity and Exits from Farming
Award.AbstractNarration:
The farm sector in Japan is subject to significant economic distortions. These distortions, consequences of legislative activity in the 1950?s and 1960?s, have resulted in a flagging agricultural economy. Total agricultural output has declined significantly over the past three decades and the amount of farmland being abandoned is at record levels. Japan?s Prime Minister, Shinzo Abe, has targeted the agricultural sector for structural reform as part of a plan for overall economic growth. The success of reform efforts will ultimately depend on the state of productivity in Japanese agriculture and the factors causing farmers to exit farming. Internal restructuring is critical to intrasectoral growth, but the dynamics of these processes are not well understood. As a general study of industry dynamics, this project will provide empirical results pertinent to agricultural and industrial economies beyond Japan. The research is conducted in collaboration with Dr. Tadashi Sonoda of Nagoya University who is an expert on Japanese farm households.

Standard economic models based on the behavior of farm households will motivate the use of reduced form statistical modeling. A Bayesian hierarchical model will be specified to determine linkages between net farm exits over a period of time and relevant economic and demographic variables. Hierarchical models make it possible to utilize data at both the prefecture and town levels. Because several measures of productivity and market distortion are only available at the prefecture level, this modeling flexibility is especially important. Production frontiers estimated from aggregate data will allow inference of the relationship between productivity and farm exit through the use of secondary equations. The results of this approach will make it possible to assess the factors influencing aggregate entry and exit from the farm sector. Additionally, this study will demonstrate the importance of productivity dynamics in understanding the changing compositions of agricultural economies. This NSF EAPSI award supports the research of a U.S. graduate student and is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research examines the factors that cause Japanese farmers to exit the farm sector. It relies on aggregate data from several sources, including the Agricultural Census, Population Census, and Survey of Farm Management and Economy at several levels: town and prefecture. Like previous literature, the theoretical model is a simple representation of the farm operator's problem of maximizing expected discounted utility subject to several constraints.

Specifying net farm exits as the dependent variable, we assume that the theoretical model may be simplified to a set of reduced form equations. Because of the multilevel structure of the Japanese data, we used a Bayesian hierarchical model estimated via Hamiltonian Monte Carlo to capture the predictive importance of several exogenous factors associated with net exit rates.

We found that the extent of off-farm labor in a town is associated with net exit rates. Towns with farmers deriving a majority of their income from off-farm sources are more likely to have a large number of exits. The share of farmers with less than half of their income coming from off-farm work is negatively associated with exit rates; small amounts of off farm income stabilize occupation migration. As expected, towns with a large population of elderly farmers are more likely to experience many exits from the sector. However, towns with farmers in their forties and fifties experience less exits. At the prefecture level, high levels of unemployment keep farmers on the farm. Government acreage control programs did not have any noticeable effect on the rate at which farmers leave farming.

Preliminary results from this research were presented at the 2015 Agricultural and Applied Economics Association Annual Meeting in San Francisco, CA.  The project also led to continued collaboration with Dr. Tadashi Sonoda of Nagoya University. It is expected that results of this research will be published in academic journals and will lead to additional interaction between the constituent individuals and organizations of the project.
